title: Caving in Snowdonia
strapline: Descend into Snowdonia's slate heart, where history and adventure collide.
metaTitle: Caving Snowdonia | Underground Adventures | Adventure Wales
metaDescription: Explore Snowdonia's incredible slate mines and caverns. Discover guided caving tours and unique underground adventures. Book your trip today!
heroAlt: Entrance to a flooded slate mine tunnel in Cwmorthin, Snowdonia
introduction:
Snowdonia. It's not just mountains and hiking. Lurking beneath the surface is a labyrinth of forgotten slate mines, ancient copper workings, and natural cave systems, making it a world-class destination for caving in Snowdonia. Forget the over-sanitized tourist caves elsewhere; here, you’re getting a genuine glimpse into Wales' industrial past and raw geological beauty.

Think miles of flooded tunnels, crumbling chambers echoing with the ghosts of miners, and the occasional glimpse of a rare bat. It's a proper adventure, demanding a level of fitness and a willingness to get muddy. Caving in Snowdonia isn’t for the faint of heart or the claustrophobic! But if you're up for a challenge, it's an unforgettable experience.

There are options for all experience levels, from the commercially run adventures at Go Below and Zip World, which are perfect for beginners and families (though pricey), to the more serious, independent exploration of abandoned slate mines like Cwmorthin, requiring proper equipment and experience. I’m talking headlamps, waterproofs, and a good dose of common sense. Always check water levels and inform someone of your plans before heading underground.

One of the best things about caving here is the sheer history steeped within the slate. You're literally walking in the footsteps of generations of Welsh miners, imagining the conditions they endured to carve a living from this unforgiving landscape. It's a humbling and awe-inspiring experience that blends adventure with a poignant sense of place. Just remember to respect the environment, leave no trace, and stick to marked paths where they exist. This is a fragile and historically important environment, so tread carefully.
bestSeason: Year-round, but spring and summer (May-September) offer the most stable weather conditions above ground.

spots.name: Cwmorthin Slate Mine
spots.description: A legendary, semi-flooded slate mine offering a challenging but rewarding caving experience. Expect wading through water, navigating collapsed tunnels, and seeing remnants of the mining operation. Proper equipment and experience are essential.
spots.bestFor: Experienced cavers with proper equipment and navigation skills.
spots.notSuitableFor: Beginners, those with claustrophobia, or anyone without appropriate safety gear.
spots.bestSeason: May-September (avoid after heavy rain due to flooding)
spots.parking: Park responsibly in Tanygrisiau village and walk up the old incline. Parking is limited and fills up quickly, especially on weekends. Consider arriving early.
spots.insiderTip: Check water levels beforehand – they can fluctuate rapidly after rain. Talk to locals in Tanygrisiau for recent conditions.

spots.name: Go Below Underground Adventures
spots.description: A professionally run caving adventure in Blaenau Ffestiniog. Choose from various routes and activities, including zip lines, rope bridges, and abseiling. Suitable for all skill levels, with expert guides providing equipment and instruction.
spots.bestFor: Beginners, families, and those looking for a safe and exciting caving experience.
spots.notSuitableFor: Experienced cavers seeking a wild, unguided adventure.
spots.parking: Designated parking at the Go Below site in Blaenau Ffestiniog. Ample space is available.
spots.insiderTip: Book in advance, especially during peak season. They offer different adventures for different age groups and fitness levels.

spots.name: Llechwedd Slate Caverns
spots.description: While not technically caving, the Deep Mine Tour at Llechwedd offers a fascinating insight into the history of slate mining. Descend deep underground via a narrow gauge railway and learn about the lives of the Victorian miners. A more sedate experience than true caving, but still worthwhile.
spots.bestFor: Families, history buffs, and those with mobility issues.
spots.notSuitableFor: Experienced cavers seeking a challenging adventure.
spots.parking: Ample parking at Llechwedd Slate Caverns.
spots.insiderTip: Combine the Deep Mine Tour with the Quarry Explorer tour for a full day out.

spots.name: Sygun Copper Mine
spots.description: Explore the historic Sygun Copper Mine, venturing into winding tunnels and chambers. Discover the rich history of copper mining in the area and marvel at the geological formations. A guided tour provides valuable insights.
spots.bestFor: History enthusiasts, families, and those curious about copper mining.
spots.notSuitableFor: Experienced cavers seeking a raw, unguided exploration.
spots.parking: Designated parking available at Sygun Copper Mine.
spots.insiderTip: Check the opening times, particularly during off-season, as they can be limited. The gift shop offers unique copper-related souvenirs.

spots.name: Zip World Caverns
spots.description: Experience an adrenaline-fueled adventure at Zip World Caverns. Navigate an underground assault course with zip lines, rope bridges, and tunnels carved into the slate. A fun and exciting way to explore the underground world.
spots.bestFor: Thrill-seekers, families, and groups looking for an active adventure.
spots.notSuitableFor: Those with a fear of heights or limited mobility.
spots.parking: Parking available at the Zip World Caverns site.
spots.insiderTip: Wear comfortable clothing and closed-toe shoes. Book in advance as it's a popular attraction.

spots.name: Rhys's Chambers (Cwmorthin Extension)
spots.description: For experienced explorers of Cwmorthin, Rhys's Chambers offers a challenging extension involving navigating more flooded sections and complex passages. Expect colder water and a higher risk of getting lost. This is *not* for the faint of heart.
spots.duration: 4-5 hours (as part of a longer Cwmorthin trip)
spots.bestFor: Experienced Cwmorthin cavers only, those with strong navigation skills and cold-water experience.
spots.notSuitableFor: Anyone not intimately familiar with Cwmorthin, or without cold-water wetsuit/drysuit.
spots.parking: Park responsibly in Tanygrisiau village and walk up the old incline. Parking is limited and fills up quickly, especially on weekends. Consider arriving early.
spots.insiderTip: Take a very, very detailed map and compass. GPS doesn't work well underground and you need to be able to navigate even if your headlamp fails.

spots.name: Braichgoch Slate Mine (exterior only)
spots.description: While access *inside* Braichgoch is generally discouraged due to its unstable condition, exploring the exterior remains and admiring the sheer scale of the mine is still worthwhile. Massive slate tips, ruined buildings, and remnants of the incline railway tell the story of a once-thriving industry. Take care near the edges.
spots.bestFor: History buffs, photographers, those interested in industrial heritage.
spots.notSuitableFor: Entering the mine itself is not recommended due to safety concerns.
spots.bestSeason: Year-round, but better visibility in good weather.
spots.parking: Limited roadside parking near the mine entrance. Park considerately.
spots.insiderTip: Combine a visit to Braichgoch with a walk in the nearby forest for a pleasant day out.

practicalInfo.weather: Snowdonia's weather is notoriously unpredictable. Even on a sunny day, conditions underground can be cold and damp. Rain can quickly cause flooding in mines, making them dangerous to enter. Check the forecast and be prepared for all eventualities.
gearChecklist: Headlamp with spare batteries – Absolutely essential, even on guided tours.
Waterproof jacket and trousers – To keep you dry and warm in the damp conditions.
Sturdy waterproof boots – With good ankle support for uneven terrain.
Gloves – To protect your hands from sharp rocks and cold water.
Helmet – Essential in mines to protect from falling debris. (Often provided on guided tours).
Wetsuit or drysuit (for Cwmorthin/independent exploration) – The water is cold!
Warm layers – Fleece or wool base layers to maintain body temperature.
Food and water – Even short trips can be tiring and dehydrating.
First-aid kit – Including blister treatment and antiseptic wipes.
Map and compass – For independent exploration; know how to use them!

gettingThere.publicTransport: Bangor and Llandudno Junction are the main train stations for accessing Snowdonia. From there, local buses and the Snowdon Sherpa service connect to many villages and trailheads.
gettingThere.parkingTips: Parking in Snowdonia can be challenging, especially during peak season. Arrive early or consider using park-and-ride services. Pay close attention to parking restrictions and avoid blocking access for emergency vehicles.

practicalInfo.safety: Caving can be dangerous. Never enter a mine alone. Inform someone of your plans and expected return time. Carry a mobile phone (though signal is unreliable underground). Be aware of the risk of falling rocks, unstable ground, and flooding. If in doubt, hire a qualified guide. In case of emergency, dial 999 and ask for Mountain Rescue.

faqs.question: Is caving in Snowdonia dangerous?
faqs.answer: Yes, caving can be dangerous, especially in abandoned mines. Unstable ground, falling rocks, and flooding are real risks. Guided tours are generally safe, but independent exploration requires experience and caution. Always tell someone your plans.

faqs.question: What's the difference between Go Below and Zip World Caverns?
faqs.answer: Go Below offers a variety of caving adventures with guided routes, rope bridges, and zip lines. Zip World Caverns is more of an underground assault course with zip lines and other obstacles. Go Below focuses more on exploration, while Zip World is more adrenaline-fueled.

faqs.question: Do I need a permit to go caving in Snowdonia?
faqs.answer: No permit is usually required for the commercial attractions, but for mines like Cwmorthin, there are no formal permits, but you should be self-sufficient and experienced. Always act responsibly.

faqs.question: What should I wear for caving?
faqs.answer: Wear sturdy, waterproof boots, waterproof trousers and jacket, warm layers, and gloves. A helmet is essential in mines (often provided on guided tours). For cold-water wading, a wetsuit or drysuit is highly recommended.

faqs.question: Is caving suitable for children?
faqs.answer: Guided caving tours are often suitable for children, with age and height restrictions varying depending on the operator. Check with the specific provider for details. Independent caving is not recommended for young children.

faqs.question: Can I cave in Snowdonia in winter?
faqs.answer: Yes, caving is possible in winter, but be aware of potentially icy conditions and increased water levels. Check the weather forecast and dress appropriately. Guided tours typically operate year-round.

faqs.question: How deep are the mines in Snowdonia?
faqs.answer: Some of the deepest mines, like Cwmorthin, extend hundreds of meters underground. The vertical depth of the accessible sections varies depending on the specific mine and the routes taken.

gearShops.name: Joe Brown's
gearShops.description: An iconic outdoor gear shop with a wide selection of caving equipment, clothing, and footwear. Known for its expert advice and knowledgeable staff.

gearShops.name: V12 Outdoor
gearShops.description: Another excellent outdoor gear shop in Llanberis, offering a comprehensive range of caving equipment and clothing. Renowned for its friendly service and competitive prices.

gearShops.name: Cotswold Outdoor
gearShops.description: Part of the national chain but a good option in Betws-y-Coed for outdoor gear and clothing. Offers a range of brands and equipment suitable for caving.

gearShops.name: Ellis Brigham Mountain Sports
gearShops.address: The Old School, Llanberis, Gwynedd LL55 4ER
gearShops.description: A long-standing outdoor retailer stocking a wide range of technical gear, including items useful for caving. Good for specialist advice.

postActivitySpots.name: Pete's Eats
postActivitySpots.description: A legendary climber's cafe famous for its massive portions and hearty meals. The perfect place to refuel after a day of caving. Try the 'Big Pete' breakfast!

postActivitySpots.name: Caffi Llechwedd
postActivitySpots.address: Llechwedd Slate Caverns, Blaenau Ffestiniog LL41 3NB
postActivitySpots.description: Located at Llechwedd Slate Caverns, this cafe offers stunning views and tasty food. A good option for a relaxing break after exploring the caverns.
postActivitySpots.knownFor: Slate-themed decor, views of Blaenau Ffestiniog

postActivitySpots.name: Lakeside Cafe
postActivitySpots.description: A convenient spot for a coffee and snack after exploring Cwmorthin. Lakeside location, simple menu.
postActivitySpots.knownFor: Convenient location, views of the reservoir

postActivitySpots.name: Isallt Cafe
postActivitySpots.description: A popular cafe in Blaenau Ffestiniog serving a range of meals, snacks, and drinks. A good option for a post-caving refuel.

postActivitySpots.name: The Heights, Llanberis
postActivitySpots.description: Formerly 'The Vaynol Arms', The Heights is a large pub with a good range of beers and food, perfect for a post-adventure pint.

postActivitySpots.name: Y Stablau, Betws-y-Coed
postActivitySpots.description: A cafe with local produce and good coffee in Betws-y-Coed. Ideal for a quick caffeine fix or a light lunch.

accommodation.name: YHA Snowdon Pen-y-Pass
accommodation.description: A budget-friendly hostel located at the foot of Snowdon, offering easy access to many caving locations. A great option for solo travelers and groups.

accommodation.name: Plas Curig Hostel
accommodation.description: A well-equipped hostel in Capel Curig, offering comfortable accommodation and a social atmosphere. A popular choice for outdoor enthusiasts.
accommodation.nearestSpot: Go Below Underground Adventures (approx. 30 minutes drive)

accommodation.name: Bryn Gloch Caravan & Camping Park
accommodation.description: A well-maintained campsite with stunning views of Snowdonia. A good option for those on a budget who enjoy camping.

accommodation.name: The Royal Victoria Hotel
accommodation.description: A historic hotel in Llanberis, offering comfortable accommodation and a convenient location for exploring Snowdonia.

accommodation.name: Pen-y-Gwryd Hotel
accommodation.description: A legendary climbers' hotel with a rich history, located in a stunning mountain setting. A great place to soak up the atmosphere and enjoy a post-caving drink.

accommodation.name: Dol Gam Campsite
accommodation.description: A simple campsite, ideal as a cheaper alternative to hostels and hotels.

events.name: Snowdonia Trail Marathon
events.description: A challenging trail running race through the Snowdonia mountains, taking in stunning scenery and rugged terrain. Some routes run near old mine workings.

events.name: Wales Rally GB
events.description: A major rally event that takes place in the forests of Wales, attracting motorsport fans from around the world. Some stages pass through or near old mining areas.

events.name: Snowdonia Winter Ultra
events.description: An extreme winter running event across the challenging trails of Snowdonia. Expect difficult conditions and stunning winter landscapes.

longTail: best time to go caving snowdonia

discoveredBusinesses.name: Go Below
discoveredBusinesses.address: Go Below Underground Adventures, Cwmorthin Slate Mines, Blaenau Ffestiniog, Gwynedd
discoveredBusinesses.description: Offers guided underground adventures in abandoned slate mines, including zip lines, rope bridges, and abseiling.
discoveredBusinesses.notes: A major caving attraction in Snowdonia.

discoveredBusinesses.name: Zip World Caverns
discoveredBusinesses.address: Zip World Caverns, Llechwedd Slate Caverns, Blaenau Ffestiniog
discoveredBusinesses.description: An underground adventure course in a slate mine, featuring zip lines, rope bridges, and tunnels.
discoveredBusinesses.notes: Part of the larger Zip World brand.

discoveredBusinesses.name: Joe Brown's
discoveredBusinesses.description: A well-known outdoor gear shop offering a wide range of equipment for climbing, mountaineering, and caving.
discoveredBusinesses.notes: A key gear shop for outdoor enthusiasts.

discoveredBusinesses.name: V12 Outdoor
discoveredBusinesses.description: An outdoor gear shop selling equipment for climbing, walking, and other outdoor activities, including caving.
discoveredBusinesses.notes: Another important gear shop in Llanberis.

discoveredBusinesses.name: Caffi Llechwedd
discoveredBusinesses.description: A cafe located at Llechwedd Slate Caverns, offering refreshments and meals for visitors.
discoveredBusinesses.notes: Convenient for those visiting Zip World Caverns or Go Below.

discoveredBusinesses.name: Lakeside Cafe
discoveredBusinesses.description: A cafe by the reservoir offering meals and drinks with a view.

discoveredBusinesses.name: Isallt Cafe
discoveredBusinesses.description: A local cafe providing simple meals and drinks.

discoveredBusinesses.name: Pete's Eats
discoveredBusinesses.description: A legendary cafe in Llanberis, famous for its large portions and hearty meals, popular with outdoor enthusiasts.
discoveredBusinesses.notes: A must-visit for anyone in Llanberis, perfect after a day of caving.

discoveredBusinesses.name: Plas y Brenin
discoveredBusinesses.description: The National Outdoor Centre offering a range of courses and activities, though caving-specific programs may vary.
discoveredBusinesses.notes: While not primarily caving, they may offer relevant skills training.

discoveredBusinesses.name: MUUK Adventures
discoveredBusinesses.description: MUUK Adventures provide outdoor adventures in Snowdonia.
discoveredBusinesses.notes: Requires contact to confirm if caving activities are available.

discoveredBusinesses.name: Snowdonia Caving Club
discoveredBusinesses.description: A local caving club. Contact for up-to-date information.
discoveredBusinesses.notes: Contact for membership and trip details.
